questions.text: A 25-year-old male with marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The patient's chest radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows left-sided pneumothorax with the partial collapse of the left lung. Best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is PA view in full expiration.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of a pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax in a patient with bilateral pneumonia. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’).

questions.text: Pick out the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given Xray shows Cervical rib.

Patients with a cervical rib usually show a lump and tenderness in the supraclavicular fossa.

The pallor and paresthesias are due to vascular and neural compressions each respectively.

Radiogram of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib.

However, the absence of a rib on the x-ray does not rule out the possibility of a cervical rib. CT and MRI are more sensitive.

questions.text: Corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in:
questions.solution:
The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

  • Diffuse/distal esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • On barium swallow, DES may appear as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus, but this is uncommon.
  • Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.

In esophageal carcinoma barium study will show irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins.

Double-contrast esophagram shows a large, flat ulceration (arrow) in the distal esophagus in a patient with CMV esophagitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds on the right side. A pleural effusion is suspected. What is the best chest x-ray view to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Lateral decubitus view is the best view to identify pleural effusion. It can identify as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid.

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

  • Presence of free pleural fluid 
  • Blunting of costophrenic angle 
  • Ellis-S curve – This is a radiological illusion and occurs as a medial radiological density due to the presence of partially aerated lung between the anterior and posterior fluid layers, whereas laterally the density is higher due to the presence of fluid only. The actual fluid level is horizontal.

The image given below shows a lateral decubitus view showing pleural effusion.

Marking A shows fluid layering in the right pleural cavity. Marking B shows the normal width of the lung in the cavity. The amount of pleural fluid can be approximately quantified by measuring the distance A.

Best investigation for minimal pleural effusion is USG.

The minimal amount of fluid required to be detected on imaging for pleural effusion:

  • Lateral view – 75 ml pleural fluid
  • PA view – 200 ml pleural fluid
  • Lateral decubitus - <25 ml pleural fluid

The image below depicts pleural effusion in chest X-ray PA view.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

questions.text: The intravenous urogram finding shown in the image is seen in:
questions.solution:
The image shows a thimble bladder which is seen in tuberculosis.

Thimble bladder has a markedly contracted bladder wall with reduced capacity.

Other features are:

  • Golf hole appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy
  • Usually, the bladder doesn't calcify in TB, stippled calcification may be seen.
  • Moth eaten calyx refers to the ragged, feathery calyceal outline due to irregular erosions of the calyx. It is one of the earliest excretory urographic appearances of genitourinary tuberculosis.

Other options;

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination. A Christmas tree or pine cone appearance is seen with severe neurogenic bladder (seen in the image below).

The below image shows calcification of the bladder wall which is seen in bladder schistosomiasis. It is also known as bilharzia of the bladder.

The image below shows a teardrop bladder / pear-shaped bladder characteristically seen in pelvic lipomatosis, bilateral pelvic hematoma, pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, and intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with hematuria and a mass in the left kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of an elderly male presenting with painless hematuria, renal mass, and an axial renal cortical phase CECT image showing renal lesions with irregular enhancement is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50–70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It usually presents with painless gross hematuria, flank pain, or painless flank mass.

Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis. The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement, which is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Still, it is essential to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

T1-weighted MRI is often heterogeneous due to necrosis, hemorrhage, and solid components. T2-weighted MRI is hyperdense for clear cell RCC and hypodense for papillary RCC. Thus, a T2-weighted MRI can be used for histological diagnosis. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the investigation of choice for detecting vascular invasion of RCC.

Other options:

Option A: Renal angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years, and there is a female predilection. CT findings show cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU) and absence of ossification or calcification.

Option B: Renal oncocytomas are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC, and hence, it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Option D: Renal cysts is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions needs evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

Image showing a simple renal cyst:

questions.text: Identify the Doppler waveform and the condition associated with it.
questions.solution:
The given Doppler waveform is monophasic, which is seen in severe stenosis of the artery.

A normal artery has a triphasic signal. The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosis and monophasic in severe stenosis.

The image given below shows the normal triphasic signal from an artery.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain. His BP was found to be 160/90 mm Hg. Further evaluation with CT was done and the finding is shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the clinical features of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

ADPDK is characterized by the progressive formation of epithelial-lined cysts in the bilateral kidneys that ultimately leads to the loss of normal functioning renal tissue. Many patients do not have any symptoms until they are 40-50 years of age. The clinical manifestations include flank pain, hematuria (from cyst rupture), and hypertension due to increased Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) activation.

Extrarenal manifestations of the disease include benign hepatic cysts, intracranial aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, and colonic diverticula.

Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. The nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 

Other options:

Option A and C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) and acute pyelonephritis, show striated nephrogram on CT nephrography (as shown below).

Option D: Renal angiomyolipoma show well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue on CT imaging.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure
  • The commonest cause of abdominal mass in children

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. What is the sign and the significance of the sign that is demonstrated in this image?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.

USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

Seen in craniosynostosis

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view incorporated to this imaging modality?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned :

  • Subxiphoid transverse view(also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called Perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or Pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the Anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria; the obtained x-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney, appearing like putty. In a patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria, the given image finding points towards a diagnosis of putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is, thus, always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or examination of at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine for acid-fast bacilli. The isolated bacilli are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

CT is the most sensitive modality and the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures.
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis.
    • Mural thickening and enhancement.
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma.
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis.
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done.

Other options:

Option B: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism. 

Option C: Staghorn calculus usually occurs in association with urinary infection with Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus and is not a cause for sterile pyuria. 

Option D: Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification and might be seen developing after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. An x-ray of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of falling on an outstretched hand and the X-ray above showing a fracture in the distal part of the humerus with posterior dislocation of fracture fragment are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. 

Supracondylar fractures are the commonest fractures in children younger than the age of 7 years. It typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched arm. They can be of various types as listed below:

  • Posterior displacement of distal fracture fragment occurs commonly and is an extension type of fracture.
  • Anterior displacement of distal fracture fragment is less common and occurs due to a direct blow on a flexed elbow and is often unstable
  • Lateral condylar fractures are due to a varus force on an extended elbow and may extend through the unossified portion of the capitellum into the joint space.

Other options:

Option A: Cubitus varus deformity or gunstock deformity is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture that occurs due to malunion. When the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, there is hyperextension at the elbow.

Option C: Dislocated radial head would present with a discontinuity in the line drawn along the shaft of the proximal radius (the line should normally pass through the capitellum). 

The image below shows an anterior dislocated radial head with calcification of the annular ligament:

Option D: Proximal humerus fractures are uncommon in children and will be pathological fractures (due to reasons such as the presence of a bone cyst).

The image below shows a radiograph showing a proximal humerus fracture with the involvement of the greater trochanter:

questions.text: A patient with chronic history of severe COPD comes to the emergency room with shortness of breath. Rales and wheeze are heard on auscultation and elevated JVP is noted.  Shortness of breath wasn't relieved with bronchodilators, IV steroids, and antibiotics. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the pathology behind the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with COPD has shortness of breath despite appropriate treatment for acute COPD exacerbation, showing peripheral pruning in chest X-ray, due to pulmonary artery hypertension

Pulmonary artery hypertension is associated with peripheral pruning which means that the blood vessels appear cut off before they reach the outer 1/3 of the lung. The edge of the lung fields are, therefore, often darker than usual and the central area often whiter.

Plain radiograph findings in pulmonary artery hypertension :

  • Elevated cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Enlarged right atrium
  • Prominent pulmonary outflow tract
  • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
  • Pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

Left hear failure would have showed pulmonary edema on chest X-ray (Option B)

Laryngitis would not cause pruning on chest X-ray and shortness of breath would be associated with stridor (Option D)

Patient with severe COPD without (A) and with (B) signs of pulmonary fluid overload and cardiac decompensation. Note the only discrete increase of vascular markings in (B) while the pleural effusion and the enlarged heart indicate the severity of the disease.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images suggest intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

Causes of intussusception are:

Idiopathic - most common cause in children
Pathological lead points include enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, leiomyomas, etc.
Meckel's diverticulum
A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children
In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign- this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum

Crescent in a doughnut sign.
The following ultrasound image shows the target sign seen in intussusception. 

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. It shows a coffee bean sign

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty ward with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. Her abdominal x-ray is shown below. Identify the true statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of  >6 cm
Emergency colectomy is the only treatment
It occurs as a complication of Crohn's disease
In 90% of patients, it resolves with conservative management

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. The true statement is that toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy, which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) characterized by superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show elevated levels of C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fecal calprotectin, and fecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, erythema, friability, and ulcerations. 

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological manifestations (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis), and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with symptoms of food impaction, dysphagia, and a burning sensation in his chest. Based on the barium swallow image given below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow image showing the feline esophagus sign are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Non-responsiveness to proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is often seen. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. An exclusion diet and steroids help in the management of this condition.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal atresia.

The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

The most common cause of neonatal intestinal obstruction is duodenal atresia. The incidence is 1 in 6000 to 10,000 live births. Duodenal atresia is thought to occur as a result of the failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage.

It is associated with several conditions, such as:

  • Prematurity
  • Down's syndrome
  • Maternal polyhydramnios
  • Malrotation
  • Annular pancreas
  • Biliary atresia. 

The duodenal obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases therefore the infant infants present with bilious vomiting.

Treatment is by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Jejunoileal atresia would present with a triple-bubble sign.

Option B: Esophageal atresia would present with a pouch like finding on the scan.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:
questions.solution:
The characteristic sign seen in the given intravenous urogram is the cobra head sign(spring onion sign) due to a ureterocele. 

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter.

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest x-ray image?
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray image shows "coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot (“coeur-en sabot”).
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor is commonly seen in the age group of 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B: Osteoid Osteoma

The image shows presence of metadiaphyseal cortical osteoid osteoma involving the upper end of the femur with radiolucent nidus surrounded by cortical sclerosis.

Nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma.

Image:

  • Black arrow - Nidus
  • White arrow - Cortical sclerosis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years involving the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus.

X-ray shows onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents with back pain. He gives a history of frequent pathological fractures. Identify the characteristic finding seen in his lumbosacral radiograph given below.
questions.solution:
The radiograph given above shows a Rugger jersey spine which is a characteristic feature of renal osteodystrophy. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy which is caused by hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic renal disease. 

Rugger jersey appearance is seen due to osteosclerosis of the superior and inferior vertebral endplates. This occurs due to excess osteoid formation by the osteoblasts to counteract increased bone resorption. The term 'rugger jersey’ appearance is used because there are alternating bands of increased and decreased bone density, similar to the jersey of a rugby player.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy, who is a football player, comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding as well as unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is the sign shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here. the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in glomus tumor, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus—antral sign or Holman-Miller sign

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the OPD with fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough. On examination, there is bronchial breathing on the right side and a dull note on percussion. A chest x-ray is done. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray are suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. 

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement. The patients present with red-currant jelly sputum.

Chest X-ray shows:

  • Cavitation
  • Pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus)
  • Bulging fissure sign: Classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging; or displacement of copious amounts of inflammatory exudates within the affected parenchyma. It is seen in any space-occupying process in the lung such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and lung tumors.

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. On examination, there is tenderness and enlargement of the liver. questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.solution:
The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral stricture.

The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:


In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: You have been allotted a patient with an upper limb fracture in the orthopedics ward. The patient fell on his elbow and has pain on elbow movement. On examining, the 3 bony point relationship is reversed. The examiner gives you the following x-rays and asks you to pick up the one belonging to the patient. Which one will you pick?
questions.solution:
The given patient with a fall on the elbow and reversed 3 bony point relationship is likely to have olecranon fracture (Image D). The x-ray (Image D) corresponds to the displaced transverse olecranon fracture.

The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle, and the olecranon. When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line. 

Since supracondylar fracture (x-ray C) occurs above any of these bony landmarks, the 3 bony point relationship is preserved.

Other options:

A - Galeazzi fracture 

B - Monteggia fracture

C- Supracondylar fracture

 

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: The following barium swallow is suggestive of
questions.solution:
Image shows markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing).

In achalasia cardia, the lower esophagral spinchter (LES) is hypertensive and fails to relax appropriately in response to swallowing. Sphincter spasm and delayed emptying through LES are also seen. Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of esophageal achalasia.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions
